column8: Why Dambulla is a Must-Visit & How to Do It Right
column11: As a private guide with over 20 years of experience in Sri Lanka‚Äôs Cultural Triangle, I have climbed the steps to the Dambulla Cave Temple hundreds of times, and it remains one of my favorite places to show guests. This isn't just a temple; it is an art gallery carved into rock. The complex consists of five main caves, each filled with stunning Buddha statues and ceiling paintings that date back centuries. The colors and details, preserved inside the cool caves, are incredible to see in person. Tips for Future Visitors: Buy Tickets at the Bottom: This is the #1 mistake travelers make! The ticket counter is at the bottom of the hill (near the Golden Temple statue). If you climb the stairs without a ticket, you will have to go all the way back down. The Climb: It is roughly 360 steps (about 15-20 minutes). It is not extremely difficult, but it can be hot. Take your time and enjoy the view of Sigiriya Rock in the distance from the top terrace. Dress Code: You must cover shoulders and knees. I always recommend my guests bring a sarong or scarf to wrap around before entering the courtyard. Watch the Monkeys: The path is full of toque macaque monkeys. They are fun to watch, but do not feed them or carry plastic bags with food, as they can be cheeky. Whether you are interested in history, art or Buddhism, Dambulla is unmissable. I recommend visiting in the late afternoon (around 4:00 PM) when the light is golden and the heat has gone down. A truly spiritual experience.

column8: PRO TIP: SAVE YOUR LEGS! THE SECRET SHORTCUT TO THE TOP by Travel Lunatics
column11: PRO TIP: SAVE YOUR LEGS! THE SECRET SHORTCUT TO THE TOP Avoid the main, long, steep staircase entirely! Most visitors waste huge amounts of energy on the primary path, but there's a detour that cuts off almost 70% of the climbing effort. After buying your ticket near the Archaeological Museum, ask a local or tuk-tuk driver to point you toward the "easier road" or the "security hut" near the giant seated Golden Buddha statue. There is a cement-inclined road that dramatically cuts the ascent. Use this path to get straight to the upper complex entrance. Dambulla is more than a destination; it‚Äôs a portal into history. While the large Golden Temple complex at the base is impressive, the real magic‚Äîand the part that deserves the attention‚Äîis up the ancient rock. The effort to reach the top is profound, and what truly took my breath away was the atmosphere and the art inside the five main caves: Devaraja Viharaya, Maharaja Viharaya, Maha Alut Viharaya, Paschima Viharaya, and Devana Alut Viharaya. The Standout Experience: You climb the rock in Sri Lanka's intense heat, and when you finally remove your shoes and step under the cave overhang, the temperature drops instantly. You transition from the harsh sun to a dim, cool, incense-scented silence. Inside the five main caves, the sense of scale is overwhelming. The ceilings aren't flat, plastered canvases‚Äîthey are the natural, curved rock face, painted over with an astonishing, unbroken fresco covering over 2,100 square meters. It feels less like a series of caves and more like being inside the mind of the Buddha itself, where every surface, curve, and crack tells a story. What Makes It Unique (Look for These Insider Details!): ‚Ä¢ Cave 2 (Maharaja Viharaya): This is the largest cave and holds the most secrets: ‚Ä¢ The First Flag & Great Battle: Look for the mural depicting the great battle between King Elara and King Dutugamunu. Look very closely for the flag King Dutugamunu is carrying‚Äîit is believed to be one of the earliest representations of the Sri Lankan flag! Its location is roughly parallel to the water pot. ‚Ä¢ The Gunman Proof: In the spectacular Maraparajaya mural (Temptation of Mara), look for the highly unusual detail of a man holding a gun in the far right corner. This detail is key proof that the murals belong to the 17th-19th century Kandyan era, as guns were introduced then. This mural is one of only two known to exist in the entire country with this detail! ‚Ä¢ Royal Statues: Near the second entrance, find the statue of King Valagamba (the temple‚Äôs founder), and note the restricted corner where the statue of King Nissankamalla (the 12th-century restorer) is situated. ‚Ä¢ Rare Buddha Posture: Look for the standing Buddha painted orange with crossed hands‚Äîa rare position depicting universal kindness. ‚Ä¢ Cave 4 (Paschima Viharaya): Look for the small stupa here, named Somawathi Stupa, which scholars believe once contained the jewelry of King Valagamba‚Äôs Queen Somawathi. Notice the line of separation on the plaster: the lower part is the original, and the upper part was replaced after the stupa was sadly robbed in centuries past. ‚Ä¢ Cave 5 (Devana Alut Viharaya): At the very far right end of the back wall, search for the unique black mural of the god Vishwakaruna Divya puthra, who is responsible for arts and music. Quick Tip for Visitors: ‚Ä¢ Timing: Go as early as possible (opens at 7 AM) to beat the heat and the tour bus crowds. ‚Ä¢ The View: Don't rush past the top terrace! On a clear day, the panoramic view gives you a perfect perspective of the flat plains stretching out, with the famous Sigiriya Rock Fortress visible in the distance‚Äîit's a great payoff after the climb.

The Dambulla Cave Temple, also known as the Golden Temple of Dambulla, is one of Sri Lanka‚Äôs most impressive and well-preserved cave temple complexes. Nestled atop a massive rock, this UNESCO World Heritage Site features five intricately decorated caves filled with stunning murals and over 150 statues of Buddha, some dating back to the 1st century BCE. The temple offers breathtaking views of the surrounding countryside, making the climb up even more rewarding. The intricate paintings and serene atmosphere create a sense of awe and spirituality. It‚Äôs a must-visit for history lovers, culture enthusiasts, and anyone seeking a peaceful yet visually stunning experience in Sri Lanka.

The Dambulla Cave Temple, also known as the Golden Caves of Infinite Buddhas, is a remarkable UNESCO World Heritage Site located 148km from Colombo. This ancient rock temple, with a history dating back to the 1st Century BC, offers a fascinating glimpse into Sri Lanka's rich cultural past. The temple consists of five main caves, each filled with stunning statues and vibrant paintings. Cave No. 1 features a 47-foot long reclining Buddha, a magnificent sight that is believed to have been crafted by divine hands. Cave No. 2, the largest and most impressive, houses 150 life-size Buddha statues and colorful ceiling murals depicting significant events from Buddha's life and Sri Lankan history. Cave No. 3, built during the Kandyan period, showcases 57 Buddha statues and intricate paintings from the era, offering a glimpse into the island's last kingdom before British colonization. Cave No. 4 is said to be where King Valagamba lived during his exile, and it contains a small dagoba with a storied past. Cave No. 5, added during the British period, features a reclining Buddha and several other statues, making it a fascinating mix of cultural influences. Visiting the Dambulla Cave Temple is like stepping back in time, with each cave revealing layers of history, spirituality, and artistry. It's a must-see for anyone exploring Sri Lanka.

It was a pleasure to see this piece of Sri Lankan history. I went to see the beautiful cave temples in Dambulla. There are quite a few steps leading to beautiful temple area. The walls are frescoed. There are many statues of the Buddha.  The views are also beautiful from the top.

Very suggestive sacred place: a series of rooms dug into the side of a mountain in different periods and renovated without however compromising the suggestiveness of the site. The second environment is the largest and also the richest: the eye is lost among the rock frescoes, the dozens of statues, the stupa, the "perennial drop" that marked the meditation of the monks who lived here. Take your time and explore all the corners (even the soles of the reclining Buddha's feet in the first cave!). Shoes are left after the long access staircase, before entering the sacred area; and you must have your legs covered and, for women, your arms too.

This is really a stunning site, an ancient cave full of statues of Buddha and other deities. Even more awe inspiring that it‚Äôs been around for 22 centuries. Definitely worth a visit! A couple of tips - there is a fair bit to climb, not really a hike but can easily get winded. Having said that, the views when you get to the top are lovely (including Sigiriya and Pidurangala). There are two entrances. If you enter from the temple side, you have to climb up, and then go all the way to the bottom of the other side to buy tickets (LKR 2,000 only for foreigners). There are no tickets at the top! Wonderfully majestic and really an impressive sight.

Incredible series of caves with frescoes and wood and stone statues. Very knowledgeable guide. We were a bit rushed to see it all because they were closing the doors for prayer. This was an extra on our tour and I'm so pleased we didn't miss it. Very reasonable tourist entrance fee compared to the better known sites. Don't miss it.

As many reviews have described it is best to enter from the rear side (not the Golden Buddha side). There is ample parking then a sign indicating a few steps up to the ticket office. From there is 400 rough steps to the cave temples. Most stairs are under tree shade. Close to the top is an old local lady sells flowers to place at Buddha cost LKR200. We placed them then the cleaner picked them up and threw them in the bin - perhaps our timing was unlucky. Also at the top is a shoe kiosk where you pay by donation. Being our first day we had no idea of the local currency so paid a donation of LKR2000 for 2 pairs of shoes. The man was very pleased and shook my hand with a big smile as the going rate is probably 100. Oh well it was a good day for him and his family. A TIP is to keep your socks on as the stone ground gets hot. We also paid a local just inside the entry to the temple to give us a talk but it was fairly basic. I think getting some information from he internet would have been better. We then came back down the same stairs to the car park, meet our private driver who then drove us around to the Golden Buddha. We went up the stairs but really the best viewing is down the bottom. Didn't go in the museum so can't comment about that.

You start by climbing the stairs. You emerge from roads with magnificent views. You can leave your bags at the safe deposit box at the first entrance. When you reach the temple at the top, you will encounter a wonderful architecture. For a very small fee, you can have a local prayer to ward off bad luck read and a rope tied around your wrist.

The steep walk up is very worthwhile however our driver did not inform us that we needed to cover up so we had to hire a sarong plus have money to store our shoes.  Once inside the cave temples are spectacular and very unique and I highly recommend viewing.

The  Dambulla Cave Temple in Sri Langka is a sacred pilgrimage site for 22 centuries. This cave monastery has 5 cave sanctuaries and the best preserved cave  temple complex in Sri Lanka. The mural paintings on the walls cover an area of 2,100 meters.

One of the visits that fascinated us the most. These are 5 caves with dozens of Buddha statues inside in various positions and completely frescoed with images of the Buddha's life. The ticket can be purchased directly at the ticket office located at the beginning of the steps and is more than cheap, 2000 rupees. After the ticket office, a long staircase begins, mostly in the sun. Be careful of the monkeys, they are ready to steal anything that is left unattended. Before entering the temple you must take off your shoes, you can leave them in a deposit by paying 50 rupees. This is a sacred place, shoulders and knees must be covered. It's a good idea to take at least a couple of hours to visit all the caves and admire the attention to detail of the statues and frescoes. Furthermore, from the top it is possible to enjoy a splendid view of the valley. An unmissable visit, in our opinion the most beautiful temple we have seen in Sri Lanka.
390 steps up but the caves are well worth a visit. Some great painting inside with multiple Buddha statues. Watch out for the monkey poo on the steps.

This was our first stop of our 3 day tour of Sri Lanka  there's me and my wife she's uses a wheelchair So we arrived and we had to walk up the hills to get to the top it took 3 of us to push my wife up the steep hills so we got up there it's very busy lots of locals praying lots to see and lots of history we was grateful that we saw this and recommend it

Most popular and an ancient temple in Dambulla town. This temple is very famous amount the locals and touriest as well. Very calm and silent place for meditation. Community from all religion visits here without any difference. All the necessary facilities are available.

You have to climb a lot of stairs to climb to the top (I counted 470) and it is mandatory to take off your shoes before entering the temple (poor feet!!) The show you will find will make up for everything 5 caves with 153 Buddhas of all sizes inside A mystical place
Superb temple made up of 5 caves, differently decorated. Entrance 2000 rps per person + tips for leaving your shoes.

Dambulla and its quarries will remain etched in my memory. They are absolutely spectacular and worth seeing. Include this visit in your tour of Sri Lanka because it is definitely worth it. You will be amazed when you see the paintings and statues. Wonderful atmosphere!

An ancient temple to view Buddha statues preserved in a cave. One of culturally important location and must visit if you are a tourist. Highly recommend.

Relatively easy walk up, great views. The temples themselves were interesting but quite busy. As at other sights, enjoyment and understanding depends on the quality of the guide. Although our guide knowledgeable it was a prepared script with no room for deviation!

Absolutely loved the UNESCO World Heritage Cave Temples in Dambulla. We did it the same day as Sigiriya Rock so after a 1200 step climb in Sigiriya, it was a 600 step climb up Dambulla. If you are in the area longer then doing it on two different days, would be better. If not, do it on the same day and do not miss seeing the caves. There are five main caves that you can see. You can take photographs inside the caves too but do not use flash photography inside to preserve the frescos and the serene atmosphere inside the caves. My tour guide seemed to indicate that there were no rules against flash photography (he may be mistaken) but I did not use any flash photography inside. The frescos are painted on the walls and the ceilings and are absolutely awesome to see in the dim light in the caves. Give yourself about 2 hours to see the place. There are places while climbing the steps where you can pause, take some pics and give your legs a little rest before proceeding up. There is a place to leave your footwear, a little away from the caves. There is also a small entrance fee to enter the caves. Also they do close the caves for 15-20 minutes in the morning - I think at 10 am for worship of the Buddha statues inside the caves. So be aware of that. We saw 2 caves and then had to wait outside till they reopened to see the other 3 caves. Sigiriya Rock and Dambulla Caves both are absolutely awesome and must not be missed if you are visiting the area.

On the 2nd day of our Holidays in Sri Lanka and after visiting Pinnawalla Elephant Orphanage, we proceed to visit Dambulla Cave Temple which is also known as Golden Temple. This Buddhist Temple Complex which is situated on top of mountain approximately 160 meters above the plains and is also a World Heritage site. It consists of five main caves, which house numerous statues and paintings related to Buddhism. These caves have a history dating back more than 2,000 years and have been continuously occupied by Buddhist monks. These Caves have a large number of Statues of Lord Buddha in various forms along with various other deities and important figures from Buddhist history. The walls and ceilings of the caves are adorned with vibrant frescoes depicting scenes from the life of Buddha and other religious motifs along with that of Hindu Deity, Lord Vishnu. At the entrance of the Complex, one can see the renowned Grand Golden Buddha Statue which has been well preserved along with other artefacts and attract large number of Pilgrims as well as Tourists from Srilanka and World over.

The five caves were worth the trek, with their sacred Buddhist images  dating from C3rd BC to modern times. We used the stairs to descend and I noticed that some of them didn't have handrails, which was my only complaint. It would be wonderful if they could transport people to the caves without the stairs at some point in the future.

Beautiful Buddhist temple in a peaceful location. Unfortunately only the  middle section of the cave was properly lit and the remaining  sections were left in the dark Locals enter free of charge and foreigners are charged rs 2000 per head  which I thought a bit hefty to visit a place of worship

A must visited greate heritage site & this is a really interesting please. The temple is unique and the Buddha statue quite amazing. üòç

Very ancient place in Sri Lanka to must see in your visit. This place have very beautiful and ancient paintings of the walls. This have mainly 5 caves. You have to to do a little hike to go there. But don't miss this place in your Sri Lankan journey

This was an amazing site not to be missed. Ots about a 20 minute wall up to the caves if you wall slowly in the heat. Once three of the Temple rooms were opened for viewing or praying. It was very stubbing to see how the status were perfectly craved and the painted work throughout the caves. Given there is limited to no sun exposure, the paint work has been preserved. not as high as sigriya but a nice spot to see some ancient history. the walk isn't as bad as it seems but I feel coming around 4 pm might be less hotter than going at 10 am.

Caves are fine, well lit and not much in the way of text to read so google it or bring a guide book. The caves are closed 10:30-10:45 but when open are pretty good. This Cave Temple is one of the best preserved rock edifices and the caves have numerous statues and paintings, on the walls and roofs. There is a lot of history attached to this place. Nice way to spend a few hours, beautiful caves and stunning views of the surrounding area. Tickets fairly priced. Watch for monkeys.
A place you should not miss if you are on a tour to Sri Lanka.  This gives you an idea about the rich culture and talents of the people who lived some 2000 years back.
Great experience and the climb was exciting and when you reach the top of the temple the feeling you get is medication for the soul

I really enjoyed seeing the Dambulla Cave temple while touring Sri Lanka. It is a very hot and steep walk up in the sun, make sure to take water and some socks as once you reach the top you will have to remove your shoes before you enter the temple and the stone gets very hot in the sun. The views and the breeze add to the atmosphere. This place gets busy and the caves themselves don't have much room so plan to go early or late to avoid the crowds. The paintings and statues are so impressive, this was one of my favourite places we saw in Sri Lanka.

From the car park, there is a 10-minute walk upstairs, it is steep but mostly in the shade. The caves are next to each other and the total time you need for this place is about 1 hour. The cave temples are well preserved and very richly decorated -statues, wall and ceiling paintings with vivid colours and nice details. Absolutely worth visiting. After looking at other drip-ledge caves this brings the whole idea to a new level. Some caves are lit up by nice yellow lights, which are properly positioned and I assume to give some resemblance to the candles once used in those temples. On our way out we decided to revisit some caves, but the power was down, so if you are unlucky to visit during a power outage you won't be able to fully enjoy this site. Entrance fee: 1500 LKR Guide: sign says 750, the one who tried to trick us into guiding us offered his services at 500 before us declining his offers, unfortunately, I couldn't understand him well. Some unpleasant things: - We encountered a very rude staff member at the entrance. - Scaffolding has been left inside some of the caves, despite no signs of any work going on. Most Peace full Visit to the temple , My visit to the temple after more than 20 years and this time with wife and 2 kids.This was the first time to clime the steps all along.. we were accompanied by the monkeys and the Guide explain all the 4 caves for 750 Rs  in English. What an amazing experience!!
A must visit great heritage site.  A temple complex carved under a cave with murals on the roof of the cave and ancient Buddha statues

This is a really interesting place. It's a small temple complex at the top of a hill off of the main road through Dambulla town. It is quite a long, steep climb from the Golden Buddha statue up the steps to the caves so take your time. No shoes allowed in the temple area (there's a place to store them outside the entrance) so have some socks with you as it is very hot underfoot. Once you're in, there are five main caves accessed by a small temple facade built into the rock face. In each of the caves there are lots of Buddha statues of various sizes ranging from human sized up to massive lying down Buddhas about 15 metres long. Take a note of the ornately painted cave ceilings too. Depending on when you visit, the monks do occasionally shut the caves for prayer, but no problem it's only for about 15 minutes. Tip - if you're driving or being driven, enter by the rear steps on the access road a little further into town, as this way you pass the ticket office. Otherwise you'll climb all the way up to the entrance and then have to descend by about 100 steps down to buy your ticket, then climb back up again to get in.

It was quite  a steep climb up those steps to the temple. Just a word of caution, do not visit these caves in the midday sun, which we did, rather go in the morning. The caves are pretty spectacular, but it was a bit crowded when we were there.

Amazing! It's just unbelievable to think of how old it is and how well preserved it has been kept! I recommend to visit it, it will also help you learn some history and religion which was fascinating for us.

More steps to the caves 395 to be precise. But not too bad a climb. The 5 caves are well looked after and worth seeing, The surrounding views were beautiful.

At the outset - understand that this is a monument on a hill. So it involves climbing around 300 steps and the climb is not easy. Wow, what a place to visit.  You must have shoulders and knees covered but you can hire a wrap at ¬£1. It‚Äôs hot and many steps to climb so take water with you.  I was amazed at this place.

We stopped off here on our way to sigiriya and honestly wished we didn't bother. You have to walk all the way up to the entrance to the temples and walk back down the other side to get a ticket. You get constantly harassed by people asking if you want a guide/ buy a 'magic box'or very sadly if you want to watch a poor snake which has been 'charmed' and shoved in a basket. I totally recommend a trip or a short visit to this awesome ancient Buddhist cave and the site that the faithful Buddhists keep and maintain in an incredible way and, therefore, gives us (to visitors) such a lovely, enchanting and unforgettable experience within the monumental site.....
Interesting both cultural and religious points of view. Quite crowded. Our guide at the caves was poor, otherwise I would have given full marks.

Well worth the visit. Very intricate paintings and some hand carved rock statues. I would bring socks as the stones are pretty hot when walking around. We started at the last cave #5 and worked our way back to #1.
A hard climb to the top from the golden Buddha but well worth it for the amazing wall paintings and statues. A must visit location!
Amazing cultural significance here. Would definitely recommend the short walk to the top with amazing museums.

First of all, it is not an easy climb to reach the caves. If the air is also humid, it will be challenging. But it is so much worth it! Be careful, you have to go barefoot and if it rains, you must have some tissues to clean yourself.

Tucked away in five caves you'll find an incredible sight of around 150 perfectly preserved statues of Buddha. There is a definite serenity about the place that makes the slog up a couple of hundred steps worthwhile. One of the highlights of our trip to this wonderful country.

Very nice religious site, a definit must see! Must watch for travellers within the region. The caves fall on the way to/from Colombo and are very convenient to reach.

On your way to Sigiriya, it is worth stopping over at Dambulla to catch a glimpse of these wonderful cave temples, ironwood forest and rose quartz mountain. This temple was built in the 1st century BC, by King Valagamba. Mahawansa (old book) says about invasion of seven Tamils from South India in Vlagamba‚Äôs reign, (103 BC). The king was unable to fight against them so he fled. Driven out of Anuradhapura by Tamil and remained in exile for 14 years. He came to Dambulla and took refuge in the cave for 14 years. In the meantime he collected an army and went back to Anuradhapura and regained the throne and his second reign was (89-77BC). After regaining the power the king wanted to show his gratitude to the temple. He converted this cave into an interior carved beautiful Buddhist temple. Before the valagamba‚Äôs arrival, this cave was donated to the Buddhist monks as dwelling place by king Saddhatissa (137-119 BC).Under the drip ledge of the main cave there is a Brahmi letter inscription. Many other King added to it later and by the 11th century, the caves had become a major religious place. King Nissankamalla gilded the caves and added about 70 Buddha statues in 1190 AD. During the 18th century, belong to kandyan period. This complex of the cave at Dambilla is one of the most impressive Buddhist temples in the world with its great number of Buddha statues and more than 20,000 feet paintings.Todat Dambulla is a world heritage site declared by UNESCO in 1991. thank you, Prasad.
Very cool and great to see people working on preserving the statues too. Loved the cave art and the staircase up to the temple itself. Must see if you're in the area

The cave located in top of mountain,  240 steps you need to claim.  You will enjoy different designs of buddha statue in different locations, in your way dow  , enjoy the views from top . It was nearly 1km of hiking to the caves from the car park. First we visited the temple museum, but there wasn't anything in it to see, total waste of time. Then we climb up the rock and reached to the caves, which was stunning. It was a quite a piece of work and survived for many hundred years. There were 5 caves full of Budha statues. When you are top of the rock you can have a stunning view, including Lion's rock. The sad thing is I didn't see any preserving measures take place around the caves.

Really great experience to see our ancestors talents!! Can't even imaging how they have built this temple under the Dambulla Cave. Bit difficult to climb but once you did you won't regret of that for sure!
A highly recommended visit . A nice walk up several hundred steps ( with beautiful views along the way ) is rewarded by a fantastic cave temple . A special place

You will have to wear clothings that covered your shoulders and knees. Else you will be asked to rent a sarong. Tickets cost LKR 1500 per pax. Before entering the temple, you will be asked to leave your shoes on the rack and pay LKR 25 for each pair. Once at the top, the cave temples are fascinating, though relatively compact. As ever there is the annoyance of having to take your shoes off and navigate the burning hot stone. Awesome place! So beautiful and interesting. Yes it was a climb, but it was so worth it! There were some local guides. We decided to pay one which turned out as a good idea. He explained very well and made the experience even better. Make sure to wear clothing the cover your shoulders en knees.

my husband and I climbed up to this cave temple, the views from the top were amazing. it is truely a very calm relaxing place. but you have to be aware that there are a lot of monkeys, they won't attack you, just leave it alone.
Overcostly. Milking in on relegious belief of people to extort cash. Other wise a very nice and peaceful place to visit.

The cost to enter the cave is 1500 rupees. There are five caves and they are stocked with many Buddhas in all manner of positions - if you are yet to visit Myanmar, Thailand, or other such Buddhist countries you will be amazed, but to be honest the South East Asian countries have many of these caves and do it all a lot better. The cave temple complex is around 300 steps from the plains. The ticket price is 1500 Srilankan rupees. Please make sure to cover your legs and shoulders. Incase if you dont cover, they provide some clothes to cover and charge 100 Rs. You have to remove shoes before you enter the temple. Cave complex is ful of magnificent Buddha Images and  Paintings of vivid colours and shapes constructed and painted from around anuradapura era. It gives proud feeling as Srilankan. anyway little bit hot in surrounding area due to the heat generated by rock. when you're visiting the temple you should wear something cover most of your body.

The best time to visit the cave is in the morning hours, early you leave better will be the hike up to the cave. Quite a decent climb to reach the cave temples, a series of temples with carvings and wall paintings built into the rockface.

A very nice place and a big temple. To arrive to the cave you have to clipm some big steps and pay a fee at the entrance. Do not forget that you have to leave the shoes at the entrance.

To reach the cave, you will have to get up a lot. In the cave, the area is barefoot, so I recommend taking socks. When we were on the ground it was hot so the feet were hot. The place is interesting. The sculptures are laid out in an interesting way in a cave.
Over 2000 years history Many beautiful frescoes and status The mysterious large pot to collect water dripping from the top 365 days but never overflows or get dry

To infer the temple foreigners must pay 1500 LKR per person. The ticket office is a bit hard to find if you start your visit from the main entrance. Inside the caves there are plenty of statues and paintings which are very nice. But at least for us it was not so impressive as we have hoped for

It is a great opportunity to learn about some of the culture of Sri Lanka and to see the many Buddha‚Äôs that are hundreds of years old. Dambulla Cave Temple is worth visiting place. Its a world heritage site. You get to see paintings related to Gautam Buddha & his life on the ceiling of caves.  From top, you also get a superb view of Dambulla Town.
Go here early to avoid the crowds and the heat. It's a bit of a climb to the Temple but it is worth it for the amazing paintings.

Like all sites in Sri Lanka, it's either going to be hot or very hot so just be prepared.  The complex is up some stairs but our guide took us to an entry that did not appear to be too strenuous a climb to the caves itself.  Having a guide makes all the difference to help through interpretation, tipping re footwear, just general things.  The temples are obvioulsy very popular with tourists so be prepared for the heat and crowds.  Don't feed the monkeys no matter if there are people selling food for them.

A must see.  A fairly good hike up stairs to the caves in the mountain top.  The temples are just breathtaking.  Start with the Temple at the far end, and work back, saving the best for last. We made a short visit to this cave temple on way to Sigiriya. It was historic and magnificent and is still used as place of worship. Entrance fee for adult is LKR1,500/- each. They told me it was okay to wear my shoes up and took it off before entering the temple. We left our shoes at the shoes counter for LKR25/- a pair, no tickets are issued for this but the man with fuzzy hair assured us not to worry as he would remember whose shoes they belong to.  Alternatively, you can leave your shoes in the open at your own risk.  There are many Buddha statues in the various caves, a bit dark inside the caves but interesting sights to see how this worship place for many centuries are within the caves.

A short hike up the hill, the Dambulla cave temples are a really great place to be. As it is a working temple, you need to be covered shoulders and below the knees, and take off your shoes when you get there, but this is normal practice around Sri Lanka. The 5 temples are cut into the side of the rock - put there by different kings across time, to show their devotion to Buddhism. Do beware of the "guides" that will talk you through the first cave and then offer to take you around the others in return for payment - you can just say no and they will leave you alone. They are beautiful, the detail and differences between them is amazing. There is also a bag drop in the Buddhist book centre at the bottom of the hill so if you come with travelling backpacks you can leave them there!
An impressive Buddhist temple in caves on top of a high hill, accessible by a long steep staircase. Worth a visit.

It is a 30 minute climb from parking lot. It is recommended to do it when it is not too hot. Also visitors are required to cover knees and sleeveless tops are not allowed. It is ok to put a temporary cloth to cover up to get inside and it can be rented from the ticket counter person at the top of the hill for a small fee. It is very peaceful and nice experience to see so many statues inside the caves.

Pictures are no longer a trusted source. This temple was not as beautiful as expected. There's a long and steep walk, hence it's quite important to wear the right shoes. But it's a very average place.

Very interesting site. As a temple dress restrictions apply No shoes but socks are worthwhile. Our guide gave us a detailed explanation which certainly helped with an understanding of this very old site
Sadly didn‚Äôt have enough time to spend at this destination. But would gladly put it on the list for our next visit to Sri Lanka.

The caves are nice, totally worth going, specially if you come from another culture where you never get to see budist temples. If you want to see the Buddha of the Golden Temple, go down the stairs right next to the shoe keeper.
Absolutely stunning visit. Our driver/guide talked us through the story of the temple, explained the paintings and ceremonies. A place not to miss.

Certainly worth a visit when visiting the region and can be easily included as part of a visit to Sigiriya etc. The frescos and Buddha shrines are located in the series of caves and are can be seen quite well from the lighting supplied. The cave temple was an amazing stop on our trip. The temples are impressive and fascinating. I would recommend wearing socks because you need to remove your shoes. It just makes walking over the hot stones more comfortable.

For a start this is a rock ledge ,not a cave.It is a long walk up and as it was lunchtime it was really hot and you must have armpits and knees covered.Maybe I've seen better buddhist sites in thailand and nepal but I was not that amazed.

we visit the place on the way to Sigiriya from Colombo,morning time(9.00 am-10.00 am) is good to climb the rock,otherwise rock heat is high,we had to climb nearly about 1/2 hrs,then we entered the cave,amazing,with Buddha statues(standing,meditation ,sleeping buddha statues were there,),inside cave was painted attractively ancient people creation, out side cave we saw nice sky view,

Mind, we did witness how this has been achieved - they are repainted.  If you are able, a must see site.  But do try to visit when it is cooler and quieter
I got a guide who explained each of the caves and as i had visited some other sites the history had made sense. You see the progression in the artwork of the statues of the Buddha.

The climb up could be a challenge for some - My count was 393 uneven stone steps up. Aim for the cooler part of the day and take water. A couple of t shirt sellers along the way, but no hard sell. The view is lovely. As per usual no shoes inside. Just leave outside or pay a small amount to store them. Inside you'll see dozens of ancient Buddha statues(up to 45') and  ancient murals. At times, especially on the climb to the top, this site is ramshackle and dilapidated.  Cons and grifters line the route.  Need a ticket?  Go back down to the gate, avoid the snake-charmer, pay to ride a tuk tuk to the ticket office, then ride back.  At the top, every stop "holy men" panhandle for "donations".  That being said, once inside the actual caves, they are absolutely amazing.  The plaster painted walls look like draped tapestries wrapped over the rocks.  Beautiful attention to detail hides among the penny-pinching hustling.

Quite quiet when we went. Quite a climb up steps to the caves. Have to take shoes off at top before going in complex so best to wear socks as stone surface is very hot if in sun. Lots of statues of budha in the caves and fabulous paintings. Great view from top over countryside

A hand held fan salesman would make a fortune here. To reach the temple, you must climb many steps and if you came at midday I imagine this would be very difficult! That said, the Cave Temples were fascinating and worth the walk. There are 5 caves to visit, however restoration work was being carried out on one during our visit so we couldn't see it.

You have to climb many steps and steep inclines to reach the temples but they are well worth it. To see the numerous Buddhas, so different and so colourful is breathtaking and to see how they have cut into the rocks to form the temples is truly mind blowing. Deffo worth a day out.

It's a bit of a hike - about 200 steps - to get to the top, but it's worth it. The statues are incredibly colorful and well-preserved. The five caves differ in size and in the number of Buddhas, but they all have something special to offer. Don't miss the Dambulla Cave Temple! One bit of advice - take an extra pair of socks. As with any temple, you'll have to take your shoes off before entering, but the ground and the walkways between the caves can get VERY HOT, so bring a pair of socks to slip on. Also, go early in the day to avoid the crowds and the heat.

Small but filled with spirituality. Incredibly well preserved statues and incredible different techniques. Some of the statues are made from a single rock, some assembled right inside, some of wood hundreds and thousands of years ago. Very important to have a guide, it‚Äôs not worth it without one. You will not understand anything. Every posture of Buda means something else and you need someone to tell you about this. It‚Äôs cheap, quiet and chill.
you have to climb many steps to reach the temple to see the many faces of the Buddha, but it is worth it, remember to buy your tickets downstairs, as they do not sell tickets at the entrance

There are 5 caves, each with paintings and statues of the Buddha, but to get there you have to climb a lot of uneven steps. They are worth the trek but as with all the tourist sites we have visited so far, they are heaving with tourists.

Dambulla Cave Temple also known as Golden Temple is a really beautiful Buddhist temple in Dambulla. You have to climb the rock but view is beautiful, and old caves with statues are amazing. There are alot of monkeys around this area, They will grab your food, bags, mobiles, even flowers. So better keep this in mind when you visit this place.
