As with all the temples in Sri Lanka they are beautiful and the history is breathtaking - go early as if you leave it too late you are with the hordes of tourists buses!  Also wear trainer socks as you have to leave your shoes outside and the ground gets really hot!

This was one of the best things in Sri Lanka. On top of a hill (a bit of a climb), there are five temples within caves, some dating back over a thousand years. There are many elaborate statues of the Buddha and artefacts alongside. A really beautiful sight with gardens alongside and a lovely walk down to the new temple

This was a visit whilst on a tour of Sri Lanka. I was looking forward to this.  There is a small climb to the top which is not too strenuous for most.  The caves are fantastic and hard to believe they are man made.  The history is incredible and all the caves are worthy of a visit. Hard to believe the paintings and Buddhas in the caves. The views are also good from the top.  You can also have a blessing whilst there. It is worth rembering that shoulders and knees must be covered and no shoes allowed when you go through the entrance.

This place is unbelievable.  The paintings are brights despite being centuries old...they look like fabric hanging from a ceiling.  The carvings are beautiful.  There's definitely a sense of of peace in the temple and on the rock outside.  Worth the climb!

We thought that the cave is at ground level but it is wrong. You have to walk up around 10-15 minutes. You cannot enter if you wear shorts. The floor is super hot at day time so socks are good options. The cave is not big but very beautiful.
Impressive temples. Worth a visit and.... the climb. In the last one, there was an agressive high pith tone. It hurted my ears, while the others did not hear anything Strange.

The sculptures are exqusite with history...the monkeys on d lookout to snatch whatever possible. And the climb with so much landscape around unbeleivable.....after this tiring episode was releived to find a quiet place serving excerlent cooling refreshing beverages n Excerlent Asian fusion food at such affordable prices.....well worth a trip down or on route to Sigiriya....the name of the place is Laki's Lounge on the Trinco rd, Dambulla......

A well preserved cave temple set in 5 sections by separate entrance. Climb a steady uphill to get to the complex mostly steps up & then down:) A combination of statues in various poses & sizes as well as many colorful paintings. Considering how old they are, going back well over a thousand years, that‚Äôs pretty impressive. Can spend a good hour plus to enjoy this site. Many tourists combine this with the equally impressive Sigiriya Rock fortress nearby, that can be seen from the top of this location !

If you climbed the 1200 steps of Sigiriya, than these 450 steps are easy for you to reach the top. Like all temples, there is a dress code. Inside this cave temple you find great sculptures. Pay also attention to the ceilings. They are very nice decorated. On your way down to the street you see a huge golden buddha. Entrance fee is Rs1500 for foreigners. This is a very interesting site.

Made a special trip here based on TA reviews and very glad we made the effort. Three very different caves the last one of which used to be a store room before being converted. The reclining Buddha which had been carved out of the granite is truly wonderful. The effort required to carve the granite with what we a know as very primitive tools must have been immense. Our guide talked us through each cave and the history surrounding it. One piece of advice, we ate in the cafe by The Foreigners car park, the food was amazing. Two Rotis and a bottle of water 150 rupees, its government funded which is why it‚Äôs so cheap.

This temple is worth a visit due to the sheer feat that was involved in constructing it. You will need to leave your shoes outside (Rs50/pair to be stored) and you will need to be covered up as you would expect. The stairs up are quite steep in places and there were many people taking a rest at certain points. The view from the top is beautiful and worth the hike just to see that. You would struggle to spend more than an hour here as there is not a lot more than my pictures show.

We arrived at the site about 2.0clock , steep climb up about 500 steps to the caves.  At the top you need to take off your shoes. But the tiles outside are incredibly hot. Tip is to take socks with you to put on when you take your shoes off. It is worth the visit especially with a guide

All you need is approx. 2 hours and a long flight of steps with an awesome view to explore these interesting caves of religious history. I was more fascinated on how these statues were placed in these caves. Note that you need to be covered from your shoulders to your ankles as a respect. Just a pareo or a sarong should suffice. Ladies no baring of shoulders please. You must leave your foot wear outside the temples. There is a fee for keeping your sandals safe. Less than USD$1. Don't leave your sandals unattended cos the monkeys will take it.

Lots of steps but worth the effort. As per the other reviewers, try to go early as the sun heats up the rocks you need to walk on. You have to pay to store your shoes to just before you go into the temples so allow 50 rupees for each set of shoes. Caves are amazing!

Worth visiting if you are passing by the temple as you can gain some knowledge about history and specially enjoy the ancient paintings. Make sure to go in the early morning or in an evening as the scorching sun can burn you during the walk to the cave temple from the vehicle. However,  it is not worthy to make your plans purposely to visit this temple itself. Just take a visit if you are passing by.

This is a very interesting temple with an amazing history. Get a guide. There are a number of steps up from the car park but they are level and easy walking. There are five temples to see each with different statues, rock carvings and wall paintings. The views are stunning, the temple flowers beautiful and the monkeys delightful. In the car park is a cafe (of sorts) and toilets. Look out for the "Jack fruit" tree with the amazing and very large Jack fruits. Tasty too.

There are a number of cave temples, most of the Bhuddist but one is Hindu. We had a monk show us around well worth the small charge. In spite of the large numbers of people the site remains tranquil. Watch out for the monkeys
World Heritage Site, beautiful and very interesting temples, bit of a walk up but worth it when you get to the top.You have to take your shoes off so socks are useful !

Steps rise steeply from the car park for approx 100m. Sari hire (for those who need to cover knees approx 100SLK). Three main caves to explore. Return to car park avoiding steep steps possible half way down far side (right at shop). Golden temple easier to reach by road rather than walking.
Wear good walking shoes to climb the rocky stairs and socks to manage the hot stones after you leave your shoes at the entrance- take your time to look at the ceilings and the statues- very rich!

The hike up to the caves is by a longish flight of steps and takes about 20 minutes. There is an extensive array of Buddha statues and painted images (>150) many of which are interesting. We were unfortunate to arrive at a time when the caves were closed for prayers and so a large number of visitors accumulated outside the caves waiting to be admitted, which meant the caves became extremely crowded and difficult to move around once they reopened - I imagine it would be much less of a problem if you are able to arrive some time after the caves have been reopened (unfortunately I do not know when the prayer times are).

For almost $8 a visit and with so many visitors, you‚Äôd think these caves could be properly maintained. They aren‚Äôt properly lit, the outsides are crumbling and wooden tables keep the visitors back. Touts bother you a lot. There is zero information on the caves around the site. No signs to the golden temple (which we almost missed). Disappointing.

You don't need a guide, just a guide book to appreciate the history and beauty of the cave temples. You will need to wear clothes that cover your knees and your shoulders.  Don't be one of those disrespectful tourists that hasn't bothered and has to borrow a sarong.  Also, it's worth wearing socks - you are asked to take your shoes off but the rock paving is very hot by the afternoon and hard to walk on in bare feet - socks help! The temples date back to the 1st century BC and there is evidence of settlement here before that.  The main attractions are 5 caves full of ancient Buddhist frescos and Buddha statues.  Because they have been protected from sunlight the colours are vivid and beautiful.  The whole place is very peaceful and relaxing - enjoy.  Also, there are lots of monkeys outside who provide great entertainment!

Dambulla is the largest and best preserved  cave complex in Sri Lanka. Very decorative  and very interesting. There are a total of 153 BUDDHA Statues. These painting and Statues are related to BUDDHA and his life. 153 buddha Statues, Sri Lankan Kings, gods and goddesses Statues. This an impressive and interesting place to visit. it's almost incomprehensible the massive and creative  work Statues and painting

A long set of steps up to the top but worth it, take your time. Amazing place goes back to 1st century  BC, lots of temples  built into the granite rock, some now under restoration but still accessible.  Incredible ceiling paintings all telling stories, Stunning views of the countryside included. Definitely a high light of Sri Lanka

We went to see cave temple which is fascinating, even more if you learned about the history of the place. Definitely worth a visit. However choose time of the visit carefully as you will walk around barefoot. You should go early in the morning when it‚Äôs not that hot. The entrance fee is 3000 rupees for 2 adults and 2 children and extra 25 rupees per pair of shoes which you need to leave outside. When you are finished proceed to Golden temple.

Climb 221 steps and take in the grandeur of Buddha carvings and paintings from a forevone era. Marvel at the golden Buddha. Be quiet and respect meditating monks. It‚Äôs another world like movies about ancient past and you are sure to be transported to times and eras now lost in history and fiction. Keep three hours at least if not more. Climb slowly resting all the while. Then take in Buddha in his glorified carvings on the walls. Out of this world experience.

It's almost incomprehensible to think about the massive and creative work that was involved in building this extraordinary rock sanctuary.  I'm not a Buddhist,  but I very much appreciated seeing the golden temples, statues,  grottoes and wall paintings.  This was one of the stops on the Gate1 tour that I was on, and I'm pleased that this UNESCO World Heritage site was included on the tour.

A very clean and neat Cave Temple in Dambulla but a word of warning to the elderly and any one with cardiac or breathing problems. The steps are over 200, uneven on a stony surface. there are stretches with no hand rails and the descent is equally telling on the knees. However the climb is finally worthwhile. Statues of Buddha bring serenity all around. Washrooms charge a lot available on descending. Must have is coconut water available all over the country. About SL Rupee 80/- for tourists. Choose the orange variety.
The only thing I can say on this place is AWESOME. You can't go in Sri Lanka and don't visit Dambulla Caves

A complex of five Buddhist temples carved into the rocks. All are fascinating. The first has a huge reclining Buddha statue and the next two each have 50 or more different statues. Make sure you leave your shoes at the entrance (25 rupees a pair).

Cave paintings dating from 1st century and onwards, together with hundreds of Buddha statues make this an impressive and interesting place to visit. There are, however, many steps to climb before you reach them, giving magnificent views over the surrounding countryside.

There are a lot of reviews in the wrong place here and Trip Advisor should sort them out. The Dambulla Cave Temple is a must-see and probably the best sight in Sri Lanka. Despite the steep climb, though you will be accompanied by well-mannered monkeys, it is worth the effort and really spectacular. There are six caves but each is separate and not very deep so you can come out to cool off it is gets too hot. The usual shoes off, though the floors are fairly clean, and cover shoulders and knees. Trips usually start at the ticket office and return the other way past the Golden Temple.

Entry Fees: LKR 1500 per person for foreign nationals There are 3 different entry points. But there is only one ticket booking office. The entry point from the Golden Temple is most painful if you dont have the tickets. From here you will have to first climb a bit, then get down, take the tickets and climb back again. Easiest option is go from the back side, pick the tickets from the booking office and get down at the next gate. From there the climb is lesser. Also there arent steps to climb from here. So slightly easier. You may be able to spot "Giant squirrel" if you are lucky. There are loads of monkeys near the cave and they snatch food. So be careful. The caves are good and maintained well. I met lot of crowd there.It can be done if you have time. But would recommend to visit in the morning hours.

well worth a trip to see the various caves and statue but if you can get a guide as the rooms can be quite complicated to understand, go early to avoid crowds or you may struggle to get in some rooms which are quiet small. Very decorative and very interesting. You can get access from the car park half way up if going by coach to avoid most of the steps from the entrance

Dambulla cave temple is an excellent way to while a way an hour or two? There are lots of steps to get to the entrance so I would suggest you should be reasonably fit and healthy to enter but once in the temple areas, Buddhas and fresco pairings are marvellous. Our guide explained many things to us whilst there which helped us understand the importance of particular things, but with or without a guide it‚Äôs a must see. It‚Äôs amazing these beautiful things were created so long ago and still exist today. Definitely worth a visit but things to beat in mind are that can be very hot in the caves, and always leave you shoes with the ‚Äòshoe guy‚Äô. It only cost 20r to ensure they are there when you get out?

An important religious and cultural site. The climb is nothing compared with Lions Rock. The caves are all highly decorated and very interesting. One was being restored but you could still go in and it was interesting to see the team of conservators at work.

We went early so was not crowded when we went up. They have a room where you can keep the luggage and when you arrive to the top they have a clock room for shoes in exchange for a fee. The temple is nice and the handwork impressive. We had the opportunity of seeing the paintings of a room being restaured and then you realised how hard work is everywhere. Nice view also from the top

Worth the trek up the steps. Stunning views along the way with plenty of places to stop and enjoy the vistas. Amazing statutes, intricate design and colours. Remember to wear your socks as the ground gets hot!

We liked this place more than Kandy (if I may compare apples and oranges).  We did as the Rough Guide recommended, i.e., started visiting the ‚Äòcaves‚Äô from the one furthest from the entrance (cave 5, the smallest one), building the momentum up to cave 2 (the greatest) and cave 1 for the dessert.  I use the scare quotes around ‚Äòcaves‚Äô, as they are not real caves, but a space under a hanging rock partitioned into five areas.  Very atmospheric place.  The entrance (for foreigners) is 1500 LKR, with additional 25 LKR for each pair of shoes you leave in a safety shack just before entering the caves.  Worth the climb.

There are two paths up to the caves. One has steps the other a steep slope. We didn‚Äôt fancy the steps so went the other way, which I believe takes a bit longer. It was a bit of a trek, but fine, definitely worth it to see the cave temple. It‚Äôs amazing how tranquil they are considering the crowds. There are 5 caves in all. The first one is tiny so some patience (and queuing) is needed. The second one is huge and the third is pretty big too. When you‚Äôve seen those three you‚Äôve seen the best of it and the other caves are just more of the same. Remember to cover your shoulders and knees. Take a pair of socks because you can‚Äôt wear shoes inside. They will look after your shoes outside the entrance for 50Sr a pair. Otherwise take a bag and carry them around. Also, most importantly don‚Äôt pose for pictures with your back to Budda, it‚Äôs a big no no. The path to the left on the way down leads you to the Golden Temple Of Dambulla, with its giant Budda, which is worth seeing just by itself. Overall this was definitely worth the trek and we‚Äôre happy we saw this impressive cave temple. Iain, London
Not so great, USD 7 entry ticket, too much crowd,It is having many top ceiling drawings, other than, no much special attraction

It's a must when travelling from Habarana to Kandy or the opposite ...The scenery around the Temple is attractive.... The frescoes and the sculptures are brilliant,... Still  t's no art but profund devotion ! We enjoyed there a great moment of spirituality.

If you are OK with the high number of steps, and warm, inside you are for a treat. This collection of 5 caves with their internal paintings has been carved in the rock. It is very busy and photography is not easy. But it is definately worth visiting

What a great treat this was. About three hundred steps you reach this amazing five cave Temple complex. The statues and ceiling art are beautiful. A very much must see. Its very hot so bring plenty of water and an extra pair of socks for walking the grounds. Long pants and sleeved shirts are required. Absolutely stunning.
An impressive collection of statues. We really enjoyed this visit. Very atmospheric rooms carved into the side of the mountain full of beautiful buddhas.

Dambulla cave temple also known as the Golden Temple of Dambulla is a World Heritage Site in Sri Lanka. The largest and best-preserved cave temple complex major attractions are spread over five caves, which contain statues and paintings. These paintings and statues are related to Gautama Buddha and his life. There are a total of 153 Buddha statues, three statues of Sri Lankan kings and four statues of gods and goddesses. The latter include Vishnu and the Ganesha. The murals cover an area of 2,100 square metres. Depictions on the walls of the caves include the temptation by the demon Mara, and Buddha's first sermon. Entrance Cost: 1500Rs Shoes Deposit: 25Rs
but be warned -360 stairs to reach the caves - but totally worth it and there are losts of resting places

We visited here mid morning when the temperature was a little cooler. A 300+ step climb to the top but well worth it, we felt. The caves are impressive, as are the carvings, and the atmosphere is very tranquil despite the number of visitors. Some great views from the top too!

Definitely a must to see.  Nice to be out of the heat and in the caves, but still it is very humid.  You need to be respectful and hat and shoes are taken off.  Make sure and check out the ceilings as well.

We visited the temple because our private driver recommended it to us. You have to buy the ticket for 1500 rupees and walk up the stairs. On top there is someone you have to pay to watch your shoes and if you dont wear long pants or a long skirt they won't let you in. There is someone waiting for those people to borrow a sheet to cover your knees, but afterwards he wants 100 rupees... The temple is not that spectacular...

We visited these temples in the afternoon and started the 300 or so step climb up the King's way about 4:30pm. It was a bit of an effort because of the heat and the unevenness of the steps. A couple of stops on the way up to observe the monkeys and take in the views helped. The whole area around the temples was intriguing and scenic - after all its not every day you see such intricate paintings  set in such an environment. You can take photos but not with flash so phone cameras do quite well here. We decended on the opposite side of the rock which takes you into the Golden Temple that houses the giant budda. We were also able to view Lion rock in the distance and teh nable to do this in reverse the following day at Sirigiya. Worth a short visit as it is unusual.

Wow !! This is an breathtaking site. We truly were awed by what we. It‚Äôs easy to spend a lot if time here. Bring a flashlight as it will help you see in some of the darker portions. Don‚Äôt miss it !

I climbed up the 364 steps and found that there is actually another way up slope without having to climb so many steps. When I reached the top, it was drizzling and the guard was very kind to allow me to sit down to rest in one of their chairs and even offered me some water as I am totally exhausted and feeling giddy/ after the climb. Remember to bring a bag to keep your shoes inside your bag or carry it around without having to store with others' shoes.  Many tourists had to use the scarf provided as the guards are pretty strict about covered sholder and over-knee attire. Honestly speaking I find that this place is over-rated after the diffiicult climb.  Been a South-East Asian, I have seen all kinds of temples so there is nothing special for me here except the structure of the building under the rock. Maybe unless one is Buddhist then it may be a must to see Otherwise, I will gladly give it a miss.

The steps up to the cave are steep but the distance is short and it's well worth the effort when you get to the top. I'm not keen on walking bare foot )stubbed my toe) but you have to observe local customs. There are over 150 images of the Buddha painted on the walls of the five caves - impressive.
The climb is worthwhile and the 5 caves holing the Buddhas are different but all good in their own way.

It is just another place of statues and paintings of 1st century BC. However, the paintings and statues were repaired and repainted in 11th, 12th, and 18th century AD. These caves were the place where Buddhist monks were meditating. This rock temple built by King Valagamba in the 1st century BC. Very disappointing to see that there is no proper lighting, cleanliness and guide service at the caves. In spite of collecting entry fees no enough attention is given to the visitors. Serious efforts are required to bring back the glorious past to the caves, statues and the surroundings.

A lot of steps! Needs some effort to reach it but caves and the view are really worth it! Entrance fee is LKR 1500, fee for shoes storing is LKR 25 per pair. Temple is functioning, you can here monks singing in the morning and in the evening if stay in the nearby hotels
The temple is situated at the top of a steep hill and several older/less fit struggled to climb it comfortably in the oppressive heat, but once there the paintings/statuary are quite stunning.

If you have travelled much around South-east Asia you will have seen all of this before, often better and probably for free. Sure, the setting is a novelty with the temples set inside five decorated caves and there are an incredible number of Buddha statues but, fundamentally, there is little to set the place apart. We had anticipated a series of caverns but the caves are actually 5 individual units. Inside each the lighting is subdued and, as a result, the whole atmosphere is gloomy and uninspiring. We have visited many, many temples in the likes of Thailand, Myanmar and Cambodia, generally without charge, and seen some stunning interiors. Sadly this place didn‚Äôt live up to those standards. On a practical level, the ticket office is located a considerable distance from the road which makes for a significant walk (for those arriving independently) before you even begin the climb up the hill. Enter at the Golden Temple, follow the sign for the Cave Temple and just keep going until, eventually, you get to the ticket office. At 1500 rupees we felt the entry charge was way too much for what is on offer. Also, remember to take a sarong or else you will have to hire one there at additional charge (including men if you‚Äôre wearing shorts).

Interesting Temple. It is quite different from the other that we have seen but to be honest the ticket price for foreigners is too expensive for a 20 minutes attraction. However, it remained as a good memory in our minds. They should do something with the touts inside who are pushy and try to give you different explanations in exchange of some money.

You will need to take a bottle of water with you and it's a 700 step climb to the top, which in humidity of 80% is a bit tiring.  We enjoyed the visit and a guide showed us around.  The colours of the paintings are incredible - they look like they were done yesterday and are 1300 years or more old..  a must visit .

Another of the must places to visit and yes more steep steps to climb as they always seem to be at the top of a hill. There are 5 caves to visit of different size, and it is suggested that you go in reverse order, 5 to 1. The ceiling painting is fantastic and there are lots of buddhas of varying size. We went at 0900 on leaving Kandy and the visit lasted 2 hours.

We were in dambulla for 2 complete days even if you can do it on a 1day rush trip. We managed to hire a great tuk-tuk driver o took us to everywhere nearby the city and more... Through rural areas and off the beaten track areas. Dambulla caves were the first Stop on the Sunset of our first day. Amazing time to visit this really charming place. They have 5 different small temples wich are full of statues and a Nice surrounding √°rea. If you need a good tuk-tuk driver for hoje Stay in Dambulla here is our driver phone Number: Sunil 0776178324

Incredible place, well worth the unexpectedly long climb up!! The architecture was breath taking and images and paintings beautiful. When you consider how old this place is, it makes it even more special! Take plenty of water as there is none on sale at the top and be prepared to say no to all the sellers waiting outside. There is a stand for looking after shoes which cost 25 SLR per pair plus a tip, but there are places to leave your shoes if you're stingy!!

A mesmerising experience. Each cave has its own character, containing beautifully carved and painted statues. The atmosphere inside is like that of an Indiana Jones movie. Also good to see the worshippers bringing their offerings.

Another must-see attraction in the Dambulla area.  And another steep climb - about 300 steps.  The five cave temples are from different time periods and varying styles.  All very interesting.  Large areas roped off to avoid destruction.  Crowds can make the smaller caves claustrophobic.  Go as early as possible.  We saw this the same day as Sigiriya.  If possible do on two separate days - quite exhausting to do both!

This complex is well worth seeing even though there are quite a few steps to climb to reach it not all of which are even. There are several caves with many figures within them and the lighting makes it very atmospheric.

Fascinating rock temple with origin in 1st c. BC is definitely place worth the visit. After taking lots of stairs up the rock, well-deserved view over jungle and distant hills presents itself. Temple that is inbuilt into rock masif is part of world heritage and despite it¬¥s honourable age, statues and cave paintings are well preserved. We arrived late afternoon and we stayed to watch sunset from the top which was wonderful. I really recommend to not skip this place if you visit Sri Lanka. Be prepared for a climb, carying some water with you, covering yourself while entering the temple and also for lots of locals trying to sell you souvenirs. Exiting area is by descending down to Golden Temple which is nice too, pretty new place but what were we more excited about was small stall with delicious local snacks next to it :)

There is a series of caves from different centuries filled with statues and carvings and rich colours. Well worth a visit and a pleasant 15 minute stroll up to the top,making friends with the monkeys along the way.
A World Heritage Site in Sri Lanka. The rock towers 160 m over the surrounding plains. It has  five caves, which contain statues and paintings. Around 400 steps to climb. Entry fees 1500 slr.

This temple has many chambers or rooms, many Buddha statues and some fantastic painted ceilings.  You need a guide to tell you about what you can see as there are not many information panels. Well worth taking time to look at all areas.

The main draw to Dambulla is the centuries old Cave Temple.  Reached by Tuk Tuk to the ticket office, you can then climb the steps or walk around to the tarmaced sloping path that approaches from the other side. There are several caves, and the guide leaflet is not very informative but hilarious for is inventive use of the English language and its summative table of how many Buddhas in each cave.  Take some time to study the statues, and also to look at the painted walls and ceilings. There's a lot to see, so wait for the crush to die down in order to have a really good experience.  ¬£ times a day, Buddha is fed, and tourists are ushered out so he can enjoy his meal in peace. This only takes 15 minutes, so enjoy the view outside and speculate on what the dish of the day is!  When you've seen enough, walk back down, avoiding the monkeys who wait to steal your fruit and belongings.  At the bottom you can also visit the Golden Temple and various other museums.  Well worth half a day to really appreciate this site, and enjoy the calm it brings.

A very nice temple with passion made in the past and without ‚Äúmade in china‚Äù plastic tingelings all over. Only minor is that foreigners have to take a totaly different entrance (walk around the whole complex) and like all over sri lanka have to pay 10-100 times more.

The walk up is scenic and the steps manageable as you can admire the view and take photos if you need a breather. Go early because it‚Äôs cooler and especially at the weekend when the locals will visit to pray. It‚Äôs the largest conserved cave temple in Sri Lanka. There are four caves containing statues and painted images of budda. The paintings cover the walls and ceilings and you need to allow your eyes to acclimatise to the dim lighting and then take in the detail. It was pretty busy on the Sunday morning that we visited and the caves were humid and full of visitors trying to get the perfect shot which created some bottle necks. Then, in the midst of all the tourist footfall,  there were the local worshippers making their offerings which helped to remind you what this place is really all about. It‚Äôs worth taking some quiet time to soak up the atmosphere and to enjoy the place before heading back down. Dress modestly, remove your shoes and turn off the flash.

The Dambulla Cave Temple is located on top of a mountain and to get to it you need to climb hundreds of steps, so wear appropriate shoes, and also it is a requirement that you wear clothes that cover your knees. The view from the top of the mountain is spectacular. The temples are well worth seeing, set into caves and with an interesting history.

This is an ancient Cave temple that dates back to the 1st century. There are five chambers with murals painted all over the walls and Buddha's carved out of stone. The golden temple is also part of the UNESCO site. Physical challenge: we came up from the cave carpark and there are a lot of steps that are uneven, we saw a lot of older people stopping to take rest along the way. There is some cover, but on a sunny day it was quite intense. The view going up is amazing. Costs: it cost 1500 rupee for the entry ticket. At the temple you must remove your shoes. There is a shoe cloak bay where people look after your shoes for about 50 rupee. I was told shoulders and knees.must be covered. I had shorts to my knees but was still required to hire a wrap to cover the lower part of my legs. Wraps cost 100 rupee to hire

We found the Cave Temple to be of interest. There are 5 caves: start at the one furthest from the entrance and work back - that way you get the best last.,Caves 3-5 are underwhelming but Caves 1&2 are worthwhile.

Sri Lanka is steeped in history and has some amazing sites. However, there is a danger you can get templed out. If you are only planning to visit a few, this is a must. 5 temples built into the cave through the centuries, dating back to the 1st century. It was amazing to see. You must wear clothing that covers shoulders and knees. Take shoes off. There is a place to leave your shoes but we put them in our ruck sack. You can‚Äôt carry your shoes or have them on display. Take water with you, there are only postcards and fridge magnets on sale outside at the top. Only criticism was there was not any information provided. We luckily had a tourist book, it‚Äôs with visiting the furthers cave/ temple first and working your way back. Try do a bit of research before you go.

Having been to a large number of buddist temple sites in SE Asia - including other cave temples - I found Dambulla interesting and beautiful but not entirely unique. If you have not been to many other places that are similar it is definitely a must visit. Otherwise, I'd recommend it if you have time and interest in this type of attraction but I would not rearrange my schedule to fit it in. The caves themselves are not very large and are quite warm inside. The walls and ceilings are painted and beautiful to look at - more so then the Buddhas in my opinion. The lighting is ROUGH for photography unless you have specialized equipment. The caves are dark with spotlights in various areas. This makes the location less of an Instagram-worthy location if that's your thing but most people should enjoy the sights just fine. I'd recommend going first thing in the morning to avoid crowds and to avoid the heat. The caves were already hot at 8 am so I can't imagine what it gets like later in the day. Also be prepared to climb stairs to get there. About 365 of them. Its steep and while I thought it was worth the cardio workout - someone who is out of shape or who has impaired mobility may not be able to make it. Tips: - don't forget to wear long pants and tops with shoulders covered. Men included. or bring a sarong to wrap around if you have shorts on. - This is a Buddhist temple so you need to leave your shoes near the entrance (there is a safe location to do so) and walk around barefoot. You will be walking on stone/concrete. - With the climb up and plenty of time spent in each cave we did the whole thing in 1.5 hours. - There is plenty of parking and clean bathrooms at the bottom of the stairs for public use.

Like most iconic sights there is a foreigners rate for entry. This is still a reasonably priced attraction though. I would say if you‚Äôre only going to do a few Buddhist temples then this is one to do. There are quite a few large steps up from the car park but worth the effort. Take a bag for your shoes as you have to take them off and not have them on show. Also you‚Äôre required to cover your shoulders and knees. Depending how interested you are the Buddhist faith will depend on how long you wish to spend here. We did the whole thing with lots of photos in an hour.
Lovely views, sacred place, lovely walk up - all together very good visit. Go early in the morning if possible and walk up the back way as views are lovely

Quite a steep climb of 365 steps but certainly worth it. The views on the way up were breathtaking. There are 5 caves to visit, all are equally incredible. Built, sculptured and painted in the 1st century. Seeing is believing, this quite literally blew me away

I'm a fan of Theravada art and architecture and I've seen most of the big sites across Southeast Asia. If that's your thing too, this could be an interesting stop. The cave paintings, especially on the ceilings, are fascinating to observe, especially where imperfections in the roof of the caves warp the murals into dreamlike waves of iconography. That said, it's not a big place, and the caves are warm and stale enough that you won't exactly set up shop for a meditative experience. Some of the charm is also watered down by the fact that it is set up with fairly harsh lighting that nonetheless doesn't help a photographer trying to capture a good image of the place. So if you want a feast for the eyes that will have to stay with your eyes only, it's not the worst way to spend a morning. The stairs are no joke, though. Be careful, especially if you're traveling with people who have impaired mobility or it has been raining recently.

A climb almost couple of kilometers up on the rock you will reach an amazing site of golden temple under the cave. It constitute 5 temples with numerous Buddha statute and the statue of Bodhisattva. Just an amazing site and worth every second and seven step. From up you will see a well preserved forest and small villages interlocked with nature. Amazing. Please visit.
We really enjoyed this, but I would recommend using a guide. Very well preserved/updated attraction with a very interesting history.

This is one of the best places we visited when we were in Dambulla and it is a beautiful place. You get nice and calming experience when you are there. Lots of information about the history, beautiful paintings and sculptures done thousands of years ago. Started with the cave and visited backwards which is the recommended way. Visit in early morning or in the evening to avoid scorching sun.

I have to say that the Sri Lanka Government takes advantage of it's tourists and charges a small fortune for visiting each site!! Saying that, I would not pass on this site. You have about 5 caves that have Buddhas of different shapes and sizes inside them. You also have a beautiful view of the area.

Stopped here on our tour of Sri Lanka‚Äôs cultural triangle. Very interesting place and worth a visit (and worth climbing all the steps). A few pointers: It‚Äôs worth having a guide with you. We were on a private tour of the country with a driver/guide and he was able to explain the history of the caves and the significance of the paintings in each one. It would have been quite difficult to have the same appreciation if you just went up and looked around by yourself. It‚Äôs a fully functioning religious site, of huge significance to the Sri Lankan people. There are periods of worship throughout the day when visitors need to wait outside. Both ladies and gentlemen need to wear clothes which cover the elbows and their knees. Transgressors were turned away without exception (and left at the mercy of the very enterprising sarong salesman on the steps outside!) Our guide intervened when a Japanese tourist was about to commit the massively disrespectful offence of photographing his companion with her back to an image of Buddha. There are warnings about this everywhere and in every guide book, so there is really no excuse.
Up the steps, monkeys, great view and amazing visit. Even the kids loved the visit. Ladies remember you need to cover up shoulders and legs.

The Dumbulla Rock Temple is an impressive and interesting place to visit. However, be warned that there are approximately 350+ steps to navigate before you reach the actual caves! I would definitely recommend going during the early part of the morning, before the heat starts to rise. As you enter the complex, you are greeted by a magnificent Buddha statue, and a general information center. Then the ascent begins. I am fairly fit, and it took me and our group about 40 minutes to get to the caves, with a few rest bite stops. Please remember to wear clothes which are longer than knee length as you will not be able to enter. They only seem to charge foreigners (approximately ¬£7), to enter the main cave complex, which I don't think is fair,  as either everyone should pay something, or it should be free for all. Either way, the caves are impressive, with several ancient paintings and statues, created over several centuries by devotees to Lord Buddha. As we all religious sites, it is always an interesting visit, and the history of the caves are impressive. As an added bonus, the views from the top are breathtaking and shows the real beauty of Sri Lanka. Definitely worth a visit, but go early to avoid the crowds and the heat.

The Dambulla caves are truly fascinating, with its 2200 year old history, marvellous murals and many statues. It is an active temple still today. Beware of the monkeys, they may try to steal any fruits other flowers that you purchase on the path ( with some really nice views) to the temple.

The most impressive thing is being there and try to imagine how it was built. Out of the 5 caves I found 1 very beautiful. I think staff at the entrance is very picky about clothes so you have to borrow a scarf from next door (100 rupees). I was wearing long trousers and very short sleeves t-shirt and they made me go for a scarf. I think it was adequate dressing code but anyway...it seemed to me they have a good business up there because once you are there, it is very unlikely to go down just to bring something to cover your arms. Also, there is a paid place to leave shoes whereas in other temples you could just leave them outside
Great views of the town around the hill top cave temple. Very well kept cave temple. Strong history. Amazing sculptures and ceiling paintings.
These caves are very impressive, start at the last cave and work your way back - each cave becomes more and more spectacular.  Just stunning and be sure to cover up.

There are two access routes, slopes or steps.  We took the slopes option but the last slope was very steep as such we used the stairs for a short distance coming down and then reverted to the slopes.  It was worth the trek.  The caves, statues, walls and ceiling paintings are amazing.

What Ab amazing set of caves with some of the best preserved works ... like most attractions the foreigner counter can be hard to find and is actually down a steep set of stairs that you need to re climb to get to the entrance - shoe storage charges, gauging guides and also compulsory sarong hiring abound - which detract from the natural beauty. For any foreigners ensure you driver goes Around the back to find the ticket office first and when you get to the entrance just say no to the guides and other items.
Though the steps are not fully safe, the temple is well maintained and inside the caves there are no birds/bats as seen in other cave temples. Must visit if you are in Dambulla.

We've seen a LOT of temples here in Sri Lanka, but these blew me away. The natural eneven stone ceilings on these caves are fully painted, and maybe because they're in caves they're amazingly preserved. They make Michaelanglo's Cystine chapel ceiling work look modern! It's worth the walk up to see these, not to mention the many Buddhas inside each one.

Dambulla cave temple is stunning. I have been to Ellora and Ajanta caves in India and I found these to be just as beautiful. It is worth the visit. This kind of work, done more than 2100 years ago is impressive on every level. The g conservation of the paintings is wonderful. Lighting could be a bit better. Some parts are rather dark. Our taxi driver dropped us off at the Buddha statue which is very far from the ticket office for the cave temple. It is not very well marked, so as long as you know where you're going, it is well worth the many stairs and higher entrance cost!
Temple with various statues of Buddha located in caves, beautifully painted. One has to climb a number of steep steps to get there but well worth it. Entry fee is 500 Sri Lankan rupees for adults.

Visited Dambulla Caves and potentially foolishly, assumed caves would be fairly close to ground level. They aren't, they are near the top of a mountain, at the top of a lot of stairs. Seeing the caves really was worth it but i have some mobility problems, so the trip up and then back down, was very hard. Not saying don't go - but do your research if you have trouble walking or climbing stairs for any distance.
A must to see when you visit Sri Lanka.Very old,culturally interesting place.You should definitely not miss it!

There is a modest uphill walk to get to the cave temple. As with all Buddhist temples, you have to check your shoes and take off your hat. The interior of the caves are filled with many different version of Buddha statues. The walls have ancient paintings. One of my favorite Buddha statues was in the first cave that you reach. Behind it, peaking out to greet you was a smaller statue of the last king of the second kingdom. He seems to have been a bit of a narcissist and was known as the Inscripton King for leaving carved inscriptions of all the great things he had done.

Get your tickets before you go upstairs!!!! After you get to the top you leave your shoes in the rack and then you are allowed to see the caves. There are 5 caves all in all. The first 3 are the most impressive ones. The paintings in the ceilings are truly impressive.

Definitely worth the visit. It includes five cave temples and more than 150 statues in brick, wood and stone. Buddha is represented laying, praying, blessing and resting. The walls are covered with beautiful ancient frescoes. Sadly, the newest frescoes are those deteriorating faster, proving how technology did not improve quality. Since it is a temple, you must remove your shoes and cover your legs and shoulders. Be prepared.

The climb, although not that long, could be considered by some to be pretty steep. The temple itself is interesting, especially considering how the caves have been dug into the rock. There are quite a few tourists, which can be expected but detracts from the overall experience.

We visited the Dambulla caves on the 18th of December 2018. The caves are at a slight altitude so I would recommend wearing something comfortable for a 20-30 minute hike up some steep steps. Also there were many monkeys near the steps so I would recommend not taking anything edible like fruits etc openly since it could attract the monkeys. Also remember that there is an entrance fee of ~1500 LKR so don't forget to buy these tickets before climbing the steps Once you climb the steps and reach the top, the view is absolutely beautiful! There is a place to store your footwear near the cave complex just besides the entrance. The caves themselves are very beautiful and I would recommend that you take your best night/low light photography equipment you have. The paintings on the top of the caves are very colorful and detailed and you would definitely want to take a few shots of these pictures. The statues of the Buddha's in various poses are a real sight to see. The cave complex itself is very well maintained and shouldn't take you more than 50-60 minutes to complete. TIP: if you plan to visit the Temple complex during the evening I would highly recommend a torch light and some mosquito repellent. It can get very dark once the sun sets and there were many mosquitos on the way down mainly because of the surrounding forests. This place is definitely worth a visit with family and friends.

Its a long climb up the 2-300 steps on a hot and humid day, but worth it for the views. There are many monkey's, even a couple of Temple cats and you can see Sigiriya in the distance. To be honest when you have visited one cave you have probably seen all that is necessary.
Definitely worth a visit if you are in the area. Took around an hour to climb up and walk around. A very unique temple with some lovely cave paintings and statues
The temple is built into the rock. It is a world heritage site and really worth a visit. Very impressive

This beautiful cave temple is placed at a considerable height but the stairs are OK and after reaching there you will fill happy. Entry fee for foreigners is excessive high in comparison to locals, it is 1500 LKR. There are total 05 caves in same complex one by one where so many Buddha statues of different sizes can be seen. Some are standing, some sitting and laying but all are nice. In Dambulla, it is must visit site.

This was our first stop in Sri Lanka and it was amazing. Wear comfy shoes for the climb (whether up the many stairs or the climb from the car park) but also keep in mind that you can not enter the temple unless you remove your shoes. If it is a warm sunny day, you might want to wear socks because the rocks outside can get pretty hot. Also I would highly recommend to get a guide. I think it cost about 1000 rupees but it is worth the money. They explain a lot of things that you would not otherwise find out. Once the tour is over, about 30 - 45 mins, you can enjoy the wonderful views from up top and take a selfie with one of the numerous monkeys. Be careful not to get to close though.

Well maintained caves laden with Buddhist history.Wall n roofs of the caves painted and preserved belonging to different centuries.Very cool and peaceful place with Buddha statues all over the caves.Serene.Just remember to visit in proper attire.Shorts and short skirts not allowed.

A visit to SriLanka is incomplete without visiting these Ancient caves with natural painting. I would recommend you to wear socks to avoid heat. Hire a guide to get a good knowledge about the history of the temple.
